  * [ ](mailto:enquiries@relocatemagazine.co.uk)

**

[![Relocate Magazine January 2020](/media/images/Relocate-
Winter2019-FC-194x274_16858_t5.png)](/digital-issues)

This article is taken from the latest issue of Relocate magazine – the must
read for HR, global managers and relocation professionals.  
Click on the cover to access the [digital ](/digital-issues)edition and order
your [printed](/relocate-global-shop) copy.**

* * *

The [CIPD](https://www.cipd.co.uk/) (Chartered Institute of Personnel and
Development) is placing considerable emphasis on people analytics data and how
it can help to advance evidence-based decision-making by HR professionals
within organisations. At its recent people analytics conference ‘Are you
prepared for the future of people data?’, the HR professional body drew
attention to building a data-driven culture and its inherent benefits,
illustrated with numerous case study examples from major businesses and public
sector bodies. The conference opened with a call from the CIPD for HR to take
up the challenge to use data to help build capability and skills. For those
beginning their careers in HR, the CIPD emphasised the potential career
opportunities that a strong focus on people analytics can bring. People
analytics is predicted to become a standalone function within HR, with various
roles available within data analysis and communication leading on to high-
level positions such as head of people analytics. Data-driven organisations
will offer clearly defined HR career pathways. Notwithstanding this, the first
challenge identified at the conference was how to change organisational
culture to become data-driven.

## Driving forward a people analytics data culture

To achieve a data-driven approach to decision-making, the value of people
analytics data must first be recognised, including how added business value
can be derived from using data, scaled up for implementation across the
business and embedded within organisational cultural values. To establish new
mind-sets and behaviours, old habits need to be broken to prevent people from
using previous decision-making processes. The first step to achieve this is to
develop awareness by being explicit about the value of data and communicating
clearly how it can be used. Continuous feedback is needed to ensure that
people keep on using data in their decisions. Facilitating the use of data in
decision-making will require guidance on the decisions needed, development of
data literacy and the input of fresh capability to prepare data. HR itself
needs to become data literate if it is to assist others in this process.
Changing the environment so that systems and workspaces encourage data sharing
and discussion will help to embed the new data-driven culture. In addition,
key performance indicators linked to data usage can help to reinforce the
culture. People analytics data can enhance business success in a variety of
ways, for example, in driving forward improved knowledge sharing, workforce
planning and improving employee engagement.

## Learning and development

The development of a smart data-driven learning and development platform can
assist businesses to improve knowledge capability. By recording how, when and
where learners access learning materials – and the information they find most
useful – learning and development interventions can be better tailored to the
needs of the business and the users of the learning materials who are required
to deliver business objectives. Business questions linked to organisational
strategy can be identified through data capture and then these questions
addressed via the development and posting online of the most relevant sources
of knowledge. Analysis of usage data can show which sources of knowledge are
most used/helpful. The curation of learning and development materials can then
be tailored to ensure the most appropriate catalogue of relevant topics are
easily accessible to staff.

## Diversity and inclusion

A further example concerns the use of people analytics data to make meaningful
change around diversity and inclusion. Understanding and appropriate
storytelling of data can be used to make links between numbers (such as
headcounts) and projecting forward as to what a workforce profile will look
like in the future. By analysing the data evidence of a current workforce
profile and recruitment and selection metrics, strategies can be devised and
enacted to hire, promote and retain a more diverse workforce. In this way,
people analytics dashboard data is brought to life with strategic actions
taken to create a dynamic workforce profile. Hence, the connection of data to
business outcomes helps build momentum for change.

* * *

## [Download our free Global Mobility Toolkit factsheets](/articles/global-
mobility-toolkit-download-our-preview-factsheet) \- on diversity, group moves,
talent and career management, and many more topics

* * *

## Workforce planning

Data analytics can also be used for workforce planning to ensure the right
people with the right skills are in place at the right time and cost. Using
people data analytics can assist in identifying and recording the skills
currently held in a business and matching them to skills required in future
operations. Data must be accurate and high quality to ensure that in
redeployment exercises, people are treated objectively and fairly. Using data
analytics to identify people and their appropriate future job roles is, of
course, unlikely to lead to a 100 per cent match between current skills and
future capability requirements. Nonetheless, it can help to identify the main
skills available and slot people into potential roles. It can also identify
gaps and training needs. A factor that also needs to be considered is location
– a people-job match may involve relocation and that may not always be the
best solution for the individual or the business.

* * *

 **Related articles**

  * [HR sidelined in AI investment decisions and implementation](/news/cipd-hr-sidelined-in-ai-investment-decisions-and-implementation-0419-rholmes)
  * [Why digital transformation creates a retention problem for certain types of employees](/articles/hr-technology-why-digital-transformation-creates-a-retention-problem-for-certain-types-of-employees-0819)
  * [UK scheme to retrain workers ousted by AI](/news/business-training-technology-uk-scheme-to-retrain-workers-ousted-by-ai-dsapsted-0719)

* * *

## Employee experience

Organisations wishing to measure and improve their employee experience can
also make use of people analytics data to aid this process. Data from
engagement surveys and exit interviews, for example, can be used to assess
employee values and how these align with organisational values and priorities.
If an organisation plans a culture-change journey, data analytics can be used
to map out where the current priorities lie and how these will need to change
to reach the desired endpoint.

* * *

### Keep up-to-date on HR news and features in our dedicated [HR](/hr-section)
section.

* * *

Line managers are key to cultural change and so they need to understand the
data and the steps needed to move to a new cultural environment. Regular pulse
checks on how employees feel about the change process can generate data, which
can be used to consolidate wins as the journey progresses and address problems
through change champions.

## Top tips

One of the key messages of the conference was not to rely on ‘shiny’ charts
and graphs. Data comes to life through storytelling with the creation of a
narrative around the aims and objectives of organisational change. Data
champions – people who understand data and enjoy communicating its messages –
at all levels in organisations are crucial to embedding a data-driven culture.
The importance of starting small and growing a people analytics culture was
also stressed. To assist HR practitioners in their data journey, ISO standards
are being developed ([ISO 30414](https://www.iso.org/standard/69338.html))
with principles being articulated that capture emerging excellent practice in
context. The new book [_Human Capital Management Standards: A Complete
Guide_](https://www.koganpage.com/product/human-capital-management-
standards-9780749484347) by CIPD staff Wilson Wong, Valerie Anderson and
Heather Bond (published in 2019 by Kogan Page) should also prove
helpful.Finally, the CIPD reminds us that it is always important to maintain a
responsible and ethical approach to data collection, analysis and
dissemination. Working within legislative guidelines, the message is to only
collect data that you need and be sure to think about its limitations when
using it to drive change forward.

# People Analytics Success Stories

* * *

**Tags:** [ HR ](https://www.hrexchangenetwork.com/tag/hr) [ data
](https://www.hrexchangenetwork.com/tag/data) [ people analytics
](https://www.hrexchangenetwork.com/tag/people-analytics)

* * *

![](https://plsadaptive.s3.amazonaws.com/gmedia/_CLF5Rhr_exchange_network_globe_0.jpg)

[ HR Exchange Network Editorial Team
](https://www.hrexchangenetwork.com/contributor/hr-exchange-network-editorial-
team)  
__03/02/2020

* * *

![People Analytics Success Stories_person-holding-white-printer-
paper](https://plsadaptive.s3.amazonaws.com/eco/images/channel_content/images/people_analytics_success_stories_person-
holding-white-printer-paper.jpg)

As human resources continues to move into the future and professionals take a
serious look at their people, one thing is certain:  the need for high
performing talent is the greatest it's ever been in the history of business.
It's for that reason leveraging data in human resources is paramount to
success.  Growth is linked to the data function and its existence across all
dimensions of HR from talent acquisition to retention.

# People Analytics

## The Stats

According to Deloitte's Human Capital Trends report, 71% of companies see
people analytics as a high priority, but only 9% believe they have a good
understanding of which talent dimension drives performance in their companies.

Why is data so important?

"Organizations today realized that good HR practices are no longer enough as
we need a more data driven approach which can lead to evidence based HR, thus
reducing human bias and subjectivity. When HR is able to make impact through
analytics, they take on a more strategic role and are able to help their
organizations gain a competitive advantage through clever use of data," Jaclyn
Lee said.  She's the Chief Human Resources Officer for the Singapore
University of Technology and Design.

> RELATED:  [People Analytics - Where Do We
> Begin?](https://www.hrexchangenetwork.com/people-analytics/columns/people-
> analytics-where-do-we-begin)

"Analytics," she continued, "also have a huge potential to increase return on
investment when the numbers are tied to business outcomes and when predictions
point to a range of possibilities that companies can plan for."

So, how are companies driving growth with [people
analytics](https://www.hrexchangenetwork.com/people-analytics/articles/data-
that-generates-discovery)?

### Talent Acquisition

LinkedIn[0](https://business.linkedin.com/talent-solutions/blog/recruiting-
strategy/2016/how-building-out-a-talent-analytics-function-saved-linkedin-
recruiting-considerable-time-and-
money?utm_source=feedblitz&utm_medium=FeedBlitzEmail&utm_content=946764&utm_campaign=0&_ga=2.87586776.1755913512.1536161130-1359123678.1536161130)
provides a fair share of resources to the HR professional, but it is also
company in need of solutions.  The social media platform for professionals has
been faced with a great demand for its services, but not enough manpower to
provide those services.  At one point, the company was growing at 40% every
year and the talent acquisition team was struggling to accurately forecast the
number of hires needed to address the demands on the company.

That's when they employed people analytics as part of their solution.  In just
one year, LinkedIn was able to predict hires within 5% of its actual hires.
That translated into money saved for the social media giant.  Also in that
first year, the company saved 15% of its recruiting budget.

### ISS and Employee Engagement

ISS[1](http://www.publications.issworld.com/ISS/External/issworld/White_papers/LinkingEmployeeandCustomerEngagement/?_ga=2.50927721.1755913512.1536161130-1359123678.1536161130)
has more than 510,000 employees across the globe, and the facilities company
had a problem.  Leaders wanted to know if it was possible to improve the
customer experience and increase profits through higher employee engagement.
To figure out a solution, ISS used people analytics to:

  1. Analyze the link strength between employee engagement, customer satisfaction and profitability
  2. Analyze data to identify HR processes that would have the biggest impact on improving employee engagement and customer experience, focusing on motivation, service quality, knowledge and responsiveness of service staff as key drivers.

In the process, ISS also found a strong link between high customer Net
Promoter scores and contract profitability.

> WEBINAR:  [Data for Dummies - How to Apply Data to
> Learning](https://www.hrexchangenetwork.com/people-analytics/webinars/data-
> for-dummies-how-to-apply-data-to-learning)

Once the company had its findings, it changed its training programs for
supervisors and employees as well as onboarding programs.

### Retention

One of the most common problems solved via the use of people analytics is
attrition.  Why?  It's relatively easy to create a business case and
demonstrate ROI.

A solid example is provided by IBM[2](https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/people-
analytics-interviews-1-anshul-sheopuri-ibm-david-green/?trk=mp-author-
card&_ga=2.86078680.1755913512.1536161130-1359123678.1536161130).  The tech
company employs a program called Proactive Retention.  Through use of
analytics, the company is able to predict which employees are likely to leave.
It is also able to pinpoint the best way to retain employees.  The program
itself has helped the company save more than $270 million dollars since its
inceptions.

Another example would be
Nielsen[3](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h3S1bUhK3Fo&_ga=2.57695082.1755913512.1536161130-1359123678.1536161130).
With the use of people analytics, the company has been able to calculate that
a single percentage point of attrition represents $5 million lost by the
company.  So, how did they mitigate that significant loss of money?  The
answer is lateral moves.  The company looked at employees who had made lateral
moves versus those that remained in the same position for a long period of
time.  The data indicated those that made lateral moves were 48% more likely
to remain with the company than those who had made no moves.

As a result, the company put the focus on lateral moves and gained buy-in from
the CEO.  Before doing so, only about 4% of employees had made lateral moves
at the company.  Following that up, Nielsen created a program called Ready to
Rotate.  It empowers employees to self-advocate their desires to take on new
challenges within the company.  Within the first six months, the company saw a
160% increase in traffic to the Ready to Rotate website.  The net result:
they saw the voluntary attrition rate for Q1 decrease by nearly half for the
same timeframe for the previous year.

### Performance

Data and the analysis around it can be used for more than finding problems and
preventing them.  It can also be used to help encourage productivity and
effectiveness at the employee and team levels.  We're talking about people
centric analytics now.

A great example of this is technology company Cisco.

At one point in time, Cisco conducted annual employee engagement surveys.
Some 73,000 employees respond.  And it took time to analyze all of that data,
share it and then implement action plans based on the findings.  In recent
years, the company decided to shift its focus from the company altogether down
to the team level.  This would allow them to get more useful feedback that
could be turned into action almost immediately.

Cisco also conducts pulse surveys.  The HR team then analyzes this data to
measure team performance and leader interactions with their teams.  This
frequent analytical review provides leaders with data that links to key
performance indicators, leading to paths of improved performance.

Roxanne Bisby Davis is the director of team analytics and research.

"We're not looking at it from the perspective of 'Who's performing badly?'
Rather, we're looking at who's great to see what they're doing and how they're
doing it, whether it's team members or leaders. By highlighting 'goodness,' it
gives the teams opportunities to say, 'I really like that approach. Let's try
it.'"

## Conclusion

People analytics is not a substitute for strategy or critical thinking.  It
is, however, another tool in the HR professional's tool box.  With the right
measurements in place, companies can use data to improve and grow the business
on every level from talent acquisition to performance.

# How to Ethically Secure People Analytics

##  [ Andy Hames Senior Vice President North America, people

Andy Hames is senior vice president of operations at [People
First](https://people-first.com/). He is responsible for identifying,
establishing and developing systems, processes and business infrastructure
across North America.

###  [Learning From The Boeing Tragedy – The Importance Of Transparency And

![How to Ethically Secure People
Analytics](https://images.hrtechnologist.com/images/uploads/content_images/how_to_ethically_secure_people_analytics_5d8b496123a87.jpg)

_**People analytics – collecting and analyzing employee data – is a hot trend
among businesses. But, how do employers and HR staff ethically secure
analytics to make informed business decisions without invading the privacy of
their employees, asks Andy Hames, Senior Vice President of Operations at
People First.**_

It is no secret that data is valuable, leading to opportunities of discovery,
insight and informed decision-making. Data collection has become a dynamic
asset in the working world especially, where people analytics is becoming an
increasingly important business strategy. In fact, according to a [recent
Deloitte
survey](https://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/Deloitte/uk/Documents/human-
capital/deloitte-uk-human-capital-trends-2018.pdf), 85% of HR and business
leaders considered people analytics to be an important or very important part
of attracting and retaining staff, building a strong reputation and
cultivating loyalty amongst customers.

![](https://images.hrtechnologist.com/images/uploads/native_assets_images/hcm_bg_5d82188ac18b5.jpg)

### Human Capital Management (HCM) Suites for High-growth Enterprises: The
Ultimate Guide [Buyers Guide]

Your HCM System controls the trinity of talent acquisition, management and
optimization - and ultimately, multiple mission-critical performance outcomes.
Choosing the right solution for your organization....

[Download](https://assets.hrtechnologist.com/research/human-capital-
management-hcm-suites-for-highgrowth-enterprises-the-ultimate-guide-buyers-
guide-128468?tfso=150406&zd_source=native_assets)

People analytics refers to the method of collecting and analyzing information
from employees that can help managers, HR staff and executives make better
decisions about business and workplace topics such as recruitment, talent
management, and workforce optimization. Before advancements in technology,
collecting insightful employee data was difficult. The end results were often
statistics rather than insights, limiting organizations’ ability to understand
and glean insights from the gathered information.

Now, companies can obtain large amounts of data about their employees.
However, this data collection can have its downfalls. The more information
that employers collect, the more questions are raised around the ethics of
tracking employee behavior and security risks. To combat this, employers and
HR teams must develop best practices for ethically collecting data to reap its
benefits in a positive way.

## **Providing Insights**

Until recently, employers lacked the ability to dive deep into the information
collected from employees. Because of this, information – collected from
surveys, questionnaires and the like – was taken at face value, rather than
analyzed on a more granular level.

Now, employers have the tools to efficiently dig deeper into employee data,
discovering the trends and patterns that drive behaviors and outcomes.
Examples of this include identifying which employees are at risk of leaving
their position, which are ready for career progression and which are more
likely to fall victim to phishing campaigns.

This information allows the company to make better informed HR decisions,
improving productivity and employee engagement – two of the most critical
issues facing employers today. With access to pragmatic people analytics,
companies have a significant competitive advantage over organizations that
don’t, with the ability to see what their employees may be lacking or looking
for without asking directly.

## **Big Data or Big Brother?**

The promise of competitive advantage has led to an explosion in the amount of
employee data collected by businesses. But the appetite for data can be risky
and raises ethical questions about how far companies should go to find
insights on employee behavior.

For example, in 2016, [employees at _The Daily
Telegraph_](https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/jan/11/daily-telegraph-to-
withdraw-devices-monitoring-time-at-desk-after-criticism) were welcomed to
work with individual sensors at each of their desks to measure how much time
was spent at each one.

The publication told employees that the sensors were to collect environmental
sustainability data, which could be analyzed to determine if office space was
being used appropriately. The data could help the company decide if it should
change the size of its offices. _The Daily Telegraph_ staff was so outraged by
the sensors that they were removed by the end of the day.

While collecting employee data is helpful, companies need to avoid taking it
too far. Employees should not be coerced into certain behaviors through fear
and wide-scale surveillance, like measuring how often an employee is sitting
at their desk.

Regardless of whether employers have good intentions about their methods of
data collection, respecting employee boundaries and protecting employees’
private information remains a priority. If not, businesses risk losing the
trust of their employees.

**Learn More:[Does Your Organization Have Its Own People Analytics Team
Yet?](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/hr-analytics/does-your-
organization-have-its-own-people-analytics-team-yet/)**

## **Who is Making the Decisions?**

While people analytics can provide unparalleled insights for organizations and
HR staff, decisions should not be made based on data alone. No matter how
sophisticated algorithms may be, they can’t replace human intuition when it
comes to making the right, moral decision.

One example of the importance of human involvement in HR is in the recruitment
process. While application testing tools and other algorithms can quickly
analyze resumes and job applications to filter and create a shortlist of job
candidates based on reported skills and experience, they are unable to
quantify individual human characteristics and qualities as well as the
potential for growth.

Recruitment and many company decisions should always remain a human process.
The role of data analytics should be to assist and educate human decision-
making processes – not replace them.

## **Pragmatic People Analytics**

In the frenzy of data collection, some organizations lose sight of what they
are trying to achieve in the first place. Collecting too much data and
measuring everything just because a company can is often where employees feel
intruded upon. People analytics should not be used to monitor employees’ every
move, but as a way to improve the employee experience and continue to make the
business profitable. By being transparent about the information that they’re
tracking, companies will continue to retain the trust of their employees. With
trust, employees may be more willing to participate in data collection. To be
successful, people analytics should be a team effort from both the employee
and the employer or HR team.

# Coronavirus Pandemic: 7 Business Continuity Planning Guidelines for HR

![Business Continuity Planning Amid the Coronavirus
Outbreak](https://images.hrtechnologist.com/images/uploads/content_images/image_546_x_273_px_5e6b41f845030.png)

_**The World Health Organization
(W.H.O.),[declared](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/11/health/coronavirus-
pandemic-who.html%20) the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19) a “pandemic” on
Mar. 11, 2020, adding that this is the first "worldwide spread" of a new
disease that can be controlled. There’s a lot that we don’t know about the
virus, but we have some idea of how to curtail its spread. That’s why the most
essential step for HR leaders today is to empower employees in times of crisis
and create robust business continuity plans. **_

While medical experts and WHO are sharing timely updates on public health best
practices, we spoke to 11 industry leaders who share tips on [how HR can
communicate with employees](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/hr-
compliance/coronavirus-hr-communication/) during a pandemic.

Here’s what companies, managers, and CHROs can do to make sense of and lead
employees through an uncertain situation:

## **1\. Build Day-to-Day Habits Around Good Hygiene and Limit Travel**

[**Jennifer Dennard**](https://www.linkedin.com/in/jennifer-dennard-822b0616/)
**, COO, and co-founder,**[ **Range**](http://www.range.co)

“As HR leaders, we play a critical role in business continuity helping teams
understand risks, implementing practices to reduce them, and ensuring
operations can continue as seamlessly as possible. For the coronavirus, we’ve
worked to define policies, resources, and sound practices, and we’ve
communicated them, with transparent, regular updates from leadership. These
practices take practice, so we’ve been building day-to-day habits around good
hygiene, limiting travel, now. Because our product helps remote teams stay in
sync and strengthen connections, we all know how to work from home because we
do it at least one day a week. Consider providing specific guidance for how
teams and leaders can operate effectively when working remotely. Create a
document detailing how teams should adjust their operations and try having
everyone work remotely one day a week to develop the operating model. Build
the practice now to avoid painful fire drills later.”

[**Harrison Monarth**](https://www.linkedin.com/in/harrisonmonarth/) **,
CEO,**[ **Gurumaker**](http://www.gurumaker.com)

"Frequent communication and simple guidance to help employees protect
themselves: Reminders on how to conduct oneself when sneezing or coughing:
best in a tissue and then discarding or into an elbow. NOT coughing or
sneezing in hand as employees tend to forget to wash hands and then touch
doorknobs, copiers, etc., potentially infecting others. Washrooms stocked with
hand sanitizers, paper towels, and soap.”

## **2\. Leverage Remote Work to Continue Business as Usual**

[**Alex Konanykhin**](https://www.linkedin.com/in/konanykhin/) **, CEO,**[
**TransparentBusiness**](http://TransparentBusiness.com)

"HR has to be prepared to assure the smooth transition of the workforce to the
work-from-home scenario, should the pandemic make a daily commute to usual
workplaces impossible or unadvisable.

“Millions of people in China are banned from commuting to work. Remote work
there is no longer a matter of convenience or economic efficiency; it’s
literally a matter of life and death. Unnecessary commute and congregating in
office buildings increase the rate of spread of the decease. However, managing
remote workers blindly is notoriously inefficient, so HR must train their
workforce to use transparency solutions, which have become an essential
element of emergency preparedness and continuity of business.”

[**Jacqueline Anderson**](https://www.linkedin.com/in/jacqueline-
anderson-b0116b3b/) **, HR director for APAC region,**[
**Nintex**](http://www.nintex.com)

**“Leverage working from home:** Unlike many businesses, tech companies can
operate using remote employees, so this is an excellent time to draw on this
capability. Ensure all employees are equipped to work from home and have met
the correct safety criteria to do so. This will show employees you support
them in their concerns about public transport travel and the closure of school
and daycares and allows those who have been exposed to the virus, but aren’t
unwell, to work while in self-quarantine.”

**Learn more:**[ **6 Essential Remote Work Tools HR Needs to Deploy for
2020**](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/mobile-workforce/6-essential-
remote-work-tools-hr-needs-to-deploy-for-2020/)

**[Courtney Bigony](https://www.linkedin.com/in/courtneybigony/), director of
people science, [15Five](http://15five.com)**

“It's HR's responsibility to leverage flexible work plans and not only allow
but encourage employees who may feel sick to work from home and take time off
without retaliation or punishment. If you don't already have a flexible work
from home policy, now is the time to create one. It's HR's responsibility to
make it as easy as possible for employees to stay home at the early signs of
sickness without fear. In short, put in place structures that make it easy for
people to do the right thing. If you have these structures in place, then when
something like Coronavirus hits, then moving remote shouldn’t affect business
as usual.”

[**Ben Christensen**](https://www.linkedin.com/in/bmchrist/) **, head of
people and talent,**[ **Handshake**](http://www.joinhandshake.com)

“1) If at all feasible, ask your employees to work from home. Social
distancing being put in place as early as possible can be key for helping slow
down the spread of COVID-19.

“2) Make sure your managers are set up for success in managing teams remotely,
and you have a support system to make sure you’re checking in on employees to
make sure they’re safe and healthy. This is a quick guide we made for our
managers when we made the choice to move to WFH and a guide we made for
individuals on expectations and best practices when working from home.

“3) There’s a lot of information, uncertainty, and confusion. HR can play a
key role in helping employees make sense of all the information, and what this
means for them and their family, leading to a happier, more comfortable, and
safe team. We are sending daily updates to our team letting them know about
any changes to our policies or any other noteworthy news they may want to be
aware of.

“4) Take a look at what other companies are doing and build off the great work
that others have done. You don’t need to figure it all out on your own.”

## **3\. Reassess If Work Done by Each Team Can Be Paused, Re-located, or
Continued**

[**Ian Cook**](https://www.linkedin.com/in/ianjcook/) **, VP of people
solutions,**[ **Visier**](https://www.visier.com)

"HR's focus is on people. Pandemics and disasters massively affect people – HR
is central to the planning and handling of these types of events. HR must
balance the needs of people with the need to keep business operations running.

**“Task 1** is to identify where people are and how likely they are to be
exposed to and/ or impacted by the event.

**“Task 2** is to identify the work that is being done by this group and
determine if it can be paused, re-located or continued with different
environmental controls in place.

“For example, one of our foodservice clients has already re-organized their
shift structure and allocation of employees to reduce the risks to their
people.

**“Task 3** is to set, communicate and manage policy and work expectations for
the broader employee base. For example, when employees should stay at home or
travel.”

**Learn More:**[ **66% of Organizations Feel Prepared to Respond to the
Coronavirus, Reports Paychex**](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/news/workplace-
wellness/66-of-organizations-feel-prepared-to-respond-to-the-coronavirus-
reports-paychex/)

## **4\. Model an Approach to Problem Solving**

[**Maggie Craddock**](https://www.linkedin.com/in/maggiecraddock/) **,
founder, and president,**[ **Workplace
Relationships**](http://workplacerelationships.com/)

“This is the time to proactively address, at a human level, the challenges
employees may be battling internally as they strive to take effective actions
externally. Validating the needs of others protects resources that may be
tough to quantify but priceless to your firm: loyalty, motivation, and
courage.

“It’s also vital for employees at all levels to make sure that the messages
they are conveying and the actions they are taking are aligned as this crisis
unfolds. Whenever we proffer a strategic plan, it’s imperative to be able to
execute this in a manner that models an approach to problem-solving that
supports the firm’s culture."

## **5.** **Communication Must be Swift, Clear, and Supportive**

[**Henry Albrecht**](https://www.linkedin.com/in/henryalbrecht/) **, CEO, and
founder,**[ **Limeade**](https://www.limeade.com)

"Now is the time your people need you the most. Your communication and the
actions you take must be swift, clear and supportive. Here are three things
employers can do right now to protect their workforce:

**“Dynamic Communication:** Email is not useful in situations like this as not
every employee has access, and email does not open opportunities for two-way
communication for all. Ensure your company has a bidirectional engagement
solution to communicate proactively and to help you react to feedback.
Administer small surveys frequently to gauge how your employees are feeling
and identify shifts in attitude, so you can adjust accordingly.

**“Show Care:** Your employees should hear from you often, feel supported and
cared for, and the overarching message must be crystal clear: stay home if you
are sick; know the travel policies; employees have a right to protect
themselves and their teams from spreading illnesses.

**“Address Policies:** Develop corporate policies to proactively address the
spread of viruses. Your workforce must know what the company is doing, how
you’re doing it, and when, in order to feel confident that any scenario has
been accounted for, which will increase feelings of safety."

[**Kandi Gongora**](https://www.linkedin.com/in/kandigongora/) **, VP people,
and organizational excellence,**[ **Goodway
Group**](https://www.goodwaygroup.com)  
  
"You must communicate that you are monitoring the situation while also
educating employees on how to protect themselves at home and at work. If you
don’t allow remote work, this is the best time to test and work out any issues
before the virus spreads. It isn’t easy and there will be challenges. You will
need to monitor its effectiveness and the overall wellbeing of employees. This
requires planning and thoughtfulness, but if everyone keeps an open mind you
can keep employees safe and productive and come away with learnings on how to
continue to provide flexible working environments."

[**Jacqueline Anderson**](https://www.linkedin.com/in/jacqueline-
anderson-b0116b3b/) **, HR director for APAC region,**[
**Nintex**](http://www.nintex.com)

"HR’s role is like that of any other business leader: understand the business
impact in all the regions you operate in; and communicate, educate and put the
correct protective measures in place. HR leaders should understand the supply
chain: Where are all your employees located and how are they affected? Tech is
known to outsource certain parts of their software development, so it’s
important to understand how those countries are handling the virus.

**“Create safe and open dialogue:** If employees feel they may be vilified for
bringing the virus into the office, they are unlikely to disclose they are
unwell or have been exposed. Communicate common myths about the virus and
explain when and how they should notify their workplace. Reinforce that there
will be no repercussions for coming forward and their privacy will be treated
with the upmost respect. It is also critical to train front line managers on
the company’s approach and what questions to ask their team.

**“Have a plan in the event of an office outbreak:** Consider how you will
communicate the outbreak, including details like when employees will need to
use PTO and when to work from home. Be clear on strategic actions like whether
you’ll separate the executive team and whether you can outsource area of work
if a team that is key to the business becomes unwell."

**Learn More:**[ **3 Low-Cost, High-Impact Internal Communication Tools for
Small Businesses**](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/employee-
engagement/3-lowcost-highimpact-internal-communication-tools-for-small-
businesses/)

## **6.** **Make it Easy for Employees to Ask Questions via an Open-Door
Policy**

[**Harrison Monarth**](https://www.linkedin.com/in/harrisonmonarth/) **,
CEO,**[ **Gurumaker**](http://www.gurumaker.com)

“Create a website or webpage on corporate website with FAQs that is updated
about the coronavirus or any other crisis employees are facing or worried
about. Frequent updates are key.

“Allowing employees to stay at home and/or work from home when they are not
comfortable at work or feeling ill. Make it easy to ask.

“Remember that uncertainty and fear are productivity killers, so have an open-
door policy and make it easy for employees to ask questions that cannot be
answered on the FAQ webpage. The more forthcoming HR departments are with
information, support in helping employees practice hygiene and safety, and the
more they can create an environment of transparency, the more employees will
be able to focus on the job during the chaos."

**Learn More:**[ **HR’s Critical Role in Emergency
Communications**](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/employee-
engagement/hrs-critical-role-in-emergency-communications/)

## **7.** **CHROs Must Provide Meaningful Input for Business Continuity
Planning**

[**Umesh
Ramakrishnan**](https://www.linkedin.com/in/umeshceokingsleygatepartners/) **,
CEO,**[ **Kingsley Gate Partners**](http://www.kingsleygate.com)

“In a health-based crisis, like the coronavirus pandemic, HR plays a
significant role both in risk mitigation and operational control. As the world
knows now, the most vulnerable populations are ones that have underlying
conditions – conditions that are protected from disclosure due to privacy
laws. The only ones with access to that information are HR executives. They
should use this to direct leadership teams with resource allocation, location
decisions, and sick leave policy adjustments. In addition, they should lean
into modifying compensation structures temporarily to protect their employees
in the long term. CEOs should depend on their CHROs to provide meaningful
input into business continuity planning and risk mitigation. They should also
set up a communication channel with remote employees that have not had
experience working in such a manner to ensure that morale is kept up during
this trying time. Now, more than ever, HR matters.”

## The DNA of success for leaders in a digital world: Microsoft Thailand's HR
head

### _Nadya Oenara asks_ Chutima Sribumrungsart _, Deputy Managing Director –
Human Resources, Microsoft (Thailand) all we need to know about leaders
requiring to be open to learning, listening to new ideas, accepting risk,
having courage to share failures, and more._

### Q What is the mindset that leaders require in order to actually succeed in
a digital world? And what’s HR role here?

The success DNA in a digital world consists of speed, agility and
intelligence. These three are critical for all members in the organisation and
require leaders to exhibit attributes that set the tone from the top, and
mindsets that support real change.

A growth mindset has become a key characteristic of the digital era. Leaders
are required to be open to learning, listen to new idea, accept risks, have
courage to share failures, give others the opportunity to try new things, and
have high empathy towards their teams.

With the expectation for leaders to transform their mindsets, HR has the
opportunity to support leaders in identifying the required behaviours, shaping
and developing these new behaviours, provide coaching, sharing feedback, and
be a bouncing board for leader.

Not only in supporting leaders, HR also has a role to play in acting as the
orchestrator in the organisation to connect teams together, ensuring that
change happen across the board and aligns with company strategies.

### Q How strongly do you find organisations tailoring their HR policies and
systems to localised needs?

Based on my experiences and observation, I see HR policies being gradually
modernised in response to the changes in business expectations, employee
profile and value proposition.

The speed of change depends on each industry. I found multinational or
international companies taking a more structural approach and most likely
customising their policies to local requirements, both from a statutory as
well as cultural context.

What really makes this effort successful is when the organisation has a clear
vision and strategies for its organisation & people management function, which
will translate into the right policies that align to support the business.

> ##### Especially in tough situations, challenges provide me a chance to
> learn, experiment and develop new solutions to help the organisation.

### Q What is the biggest motivation that keeps you going when things get
tough in your role?

My personal principle is 'everything is possible', and my positive energy is
driven from seeing positive outcomes in helping others succeed. Therefore when
I face challenges, I see them as opportunities. Especially in tough
situations, these provide me a chance to learn, experiment and develop new
solutions to help the organisation.

Most importantly, I don’t take such things personally. I focus more on the
context of the challenge and work things out from there. I make sure to
reflect on the learning and appreciate the impact of contribution, and of
course, take out time to enjoy and smell the roses. 😊

### Q In your experience, what is the biggest talent challenge Thailand is
facing, and how are you tackling that?

Digital transformation, skill economy, changing lifestyles, expectations from
organisations, and shortage of digital talents are all challenges in the area
of talent. These lead to business challenges in terms of ensuring continuity,
ability to grow at desired speed, optimising productivity and delivering great
results to investors.

It is important for each organisation to first understand that the talent
agenda is a business agenda, and not an HR agenda. It requires business
leaders to own and drive this agenda by partnering with HR.

In my experience, a simple proven rule of success is how we can engage with
the business and hold business leaders accountable in driving the talent
agenda as one of the business rhythms.

Setting expectations, defining ownership and expected deliverables on talent
topics through acquisition, managing, developing, engaging and retaining - our
role in HR is to enable people leader skills for all people managers in the
organisation and empower them to own their talent pools.

HR needs to reform how we drive the talent agenda in the organisation through
the disruption that is happening now.

### Q What can HR do to better support and add value to the organisation?

HR in the disruptive world plays the pivotal role of partnering with business
leaders to enable organisation transformation and cope with rapid changes.

Our role, capability and expectations from the organisation are also being
disrupted and we require significant transformation to lead the organisation
and people agenda. The HR world of back-office support no longer exists and we
have to shape our ways to deliver the HR function in a more strategic way,
this identifying business impact through HR methodology and deliverables.

Critical to success in making an impact through our function lies in how we
shift from HR-centric to business-centric. HR professionals are required to
reskill towards high-capability business acumen, envisioning, systematic &
analytical thinking, stakeholder engagement, and storytelling. These are all
critical capabilities to enable our role to create value to the organisation
and people.

Our success is, and will be, defined by business impact as well as customer
(both internal and external) experience, which will be driven by all HR core
services that align to business strategies.

> ##### It is my honour to provide my viewpoint as a judge to all applicants
> and also learn how the HR function in Thailand has developed and transformed
> to become a critical function in each organisation.

### Q For you, what is the most exciting thing about being a judge at the
[first-ever HR Excellence Awards, Thailand 2020](http://bit.ly/39mKEhy)?

First of all, I would like to express my sincere thank you to Human Resources
Online for this opportunity.

It is my honour to provide my viewpoint as a judge to all applicants and also
learn how the HR function in Thailand has developed and transformed to become
a critical function in each organisation. I also believe this award will
inspire our HR professionals to continue to add value to each organisation's
success.

### Q Reveal to us the one thing you will look for in a winning entry
submission by our participants.

My scoring will be based on the impact of the story from the participants. For
me, the 'how' is more important than the 'what'.

![8 HR analytics courses for new-age HR professionals looking to upskill for
the digital
era](https://images.hrtechnologist.com/images/uploads/content_images/8_hr_analytics_courses_for_newage_hr_professionals_looking_to_upskill_for_the_digital_era_5e31737dd30d1.jpg)

**_The demand for HR analytics expertise will grow in 2020 and beyond. The
right certification can help the new-age HR professional stay ahead of the
curve. In this article, we share our top recommendations from openSAP, Penn,
eCornell, Josh Bersin, myHRfuture, Udemy, Google, and the American
University._**

As an HR professional in a data-driven world, you need to stay up to speed
with the latest advancements in data analytics and how they apply to people
management. In fact, working knowledge of analytics is among the most in-
demand skill sets in HR, leading to growing interest in HR analytics courses.

![](https://images.hrtechnologist.com/images/uploads/native_assets_images/hcm_bg_5d82188ac18b5.jpg)

### Human Capital Management (HCM) Suites for High-growth Enterprises: The
Ultimate Guide [Buyers Guide]

Your HCM System controls the trinity of talent acquisition, management and
optimization - and ultimately, multiple mission-critical performance outcomes.
Choosing the right solution for your organization....

[Download](https://assets.hrtechnologist.com/research/human-capital-
management-hcm-suites-for-highgrowth-enterprises-the-ultimate-guide-buyers-
guide-128468?tfso=150406&zd_source=native_assets)

Here are a few metrics that drive home why analytics and overall [data
literacy](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/learning-development/qlik-
launches-data-literacy-consulting-why-data-literacy-is-vital-in-2020/) is such
an interest area for new-age HR professionals:

  * Globally, HR analytics [is expected to grow](https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/global-hr-analytics-market-size-is-expected-to-grow-from-usd-1-9-billion-in-2019-to-usd-3-6-billion-by-2024--at-a-cagr-of-13-7-300871414.html) from $1.9 billion in 2019 to $3.6 billion by 2024, at a stellar compound annual growth rate of 13.7%. HR professionals must be able to leverage this growth to improve people outcomes.
  * A [PwC report](https://www.pwc.ie/reports/hrd-pulse-survey-2019.html) of 81 HR leaders in Ireland found data analytics to be their no. 1 priority. While this is a localized metric, it indicates a larger trend and why professionals with analytics expertise will gain an edge this year.
  * A [crowd-sourced survey by myHRfuture](https://www.myhrfuture.com/blog/2019/3/14/what-are-the-hr-skills-of-the-future) found expertise in people analytics to be the most in-demand skill. 75% of the survey respondents reported spending at least four hours every month on learning from free/publicly available content and courses.

So, not only is the demand for [HR
analytics](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/hr-analytics/what-is-hr-
analytics/) growing, but experts in this field are also rapidly upskilling
themselves with online HR analytics courses. We looked at some of the top
courses you could take this year to prepare for a data-driven future.

**Learn More:**[ **Best Human Resource Books to Prepare You for
2020**](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/learning-development/best-
human-resource-books/)

## **8 HR Analytics Courses Geared for a New Era of HR**

E-learning and video-based courses have made it much easier for HR
professionals to keep up with the newest workplace trends. Whether you’re new
to this field or an HR veteran, staying abreast of cutting-edge technologies
like HR and [people analytics](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/hr-
analytics/what-is-people-analytics/) is key to standing out against the
competition.

We have curated a list of the eight best HR analytics courses you can look at
this year, arranged in no particular order.

### **1.**[ **People Analytics and Evidence-Based Management by
openSAP**](https://open.sap.com/courses/pa1-tl)

SAP is globally known as a technology giant, winning recognition in the HR
segment for its SuccessFactors suite. The company offers [Massive Open Online
Courses (MOOCs)](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/learning-
development/4-mooc-trends-we-expect-to-see-in-2019/) under its open SAP brand.
Take a look at its free online course on people analytics, available in
English, French, Spanish, and Dutch.

It is a self-paced course with approximately four weeks’ worth of content,
giving you an introduction to the use of HR analytics in everyday scenarios.
It’s free to access with an SAP account.

### **2.**[ **People Analytics by Wharton University of Pennsylvania
Online**](https://www.coursera.org/learn/wharton-people-analytics#enroll)

This analytics course is available on Coursera as part of Wharton’s Business
Analytics Specialization series of content. The course is available in
English, Korean, and Chinese.

_People Analytics_ on Coursera takes approximately 11 hours to complete
(although its self-paced) covering essentials like analytics for staffing,
collaboration, and talent management. Enrollment is currently free.

### **3.**[ **Graduate Certificate in Human Resource Analytics and Management
by American University**](https://programs.online.american.edu/mshram/human-
resource-management-certficate)

Completing this HR analytics course gives you receive a graduate certificate.
So, it is meant for young professionals looking to obtain the right
educational qualifications and kickstart their careers. Credits from the
course can be applied toward a master’s degree from the same university.

The course takes approximately 12–15 months and will familiarize learners with
data-driven decision making, human resource information systems, [key HR
metrics](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/hr-analytics/important-hr-
metrics/), and compliance/risk management. The course is available in English
and requires paid admission (details available on the query).

**Learn More:** **[What Is Human Resource Development (HRD)? Definition,
Functions, and Best Practices for Training
Program](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/learning-development/what-is-
human-resource-development/)**

### **4.**[ **HR Analytics - Analytics in Talent Management by
Udemy**](https://www.udemy.com/course/hr-analytics-analytics-in-talent-
management/)

HR analytics has diverse applications, and one of its most important use cases
is talent management. This includes the recruitment strategy, talent
development metrics, how to measure [employee
engagement](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/employee-engagement/what-
is-employee-engagement/), and employee compensation.

Udemy’s course (available in English) includes two hours of on-demand video
that can be accessed on mobile and television, as well as a certificate of
completion. It is designed for HR professionals with at least two years of
work experience and comes at an undiscounted price of approximately $20 with a
localized pricing model.

### **5.**[ **People Analytics by Josh
Bersin**](https://bersinacademy.com/people-analytics)

The Josh Bersin Academy has a vast library of content for HR professionals,
including a course on people analytics. It is designed for an online social
learning experience, with a learning time of 4–6 hours. It approaches
analytics from a business perspective, ideal for non-technical users.

_People Analytics by Josh Bersin_ includes five modules that delve into the
evolution of analytics, data literacy, and how to use insights for effective
communication. Membership plans for the Josh Bersin academy start at $40 per
person per month, with the content available in English.

### **6.**[ **An Introduction to People Analytics by
myHRfuture**](https://www.myhrfuture.com/an-introduction-to-people-analytics-
course)

This people analytics course can be taken by beginners and experts alike, as
it covers a wide scope of topics, ranging from basic concepts to implementable
frameworks. It’s a two-and-half-hour-long learning experience, comprising 10
modules.

Access to _An Introduction to People Analytics_ requires a subscription to
myHRfuture, starting at $32/month for an annual plan. The course is available
in English and is particularly useful for the HR analytics case studies it
provides.

### **7.**[ **HR Analytics Certificate Program by
eCornell**](https://www.ecornell.com/certificates/human-resources/hr-
analytics/)

This is an HR analytics course designed specifically for senior industry
professionals, including managers, directors, VPs, analysts, and CHROs. It
requires approximately 3–5 hours of effort every week for two weeks. Upon
completion, learners receive an HR Analytics certificate from Cornell ILR
School.

Topics covered include the fundamentals of HR analytics, talent analytics,
[predictive analytics](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/hr-
analytics/5-hr-essentials-that-predictive-analytics-will-transform-
completely/), and how to assign a measurable value to HR initiatives.
Enrollment starts at $950 per month, and you can expect an instructor-led
learning experience.

### **8.**[ **People analytics by Google re:
Work**](https://rework.withgoogle.com/subjects/people-analytics/)

Google has a set of useful learning content under its re: Work project. This
includes a basic explanation of the concept, as well as four actionable guides
to help HR professionals apply analytics in the workplace. These four guides
discuss fair pay practices, employee survey management, HR metrics
identification and collection, and how to adopt an analytics mindset.

Interestingly, the first guide ([fair
pay](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/diversity/how-to-offer-equal-pay-
for-equal-work/)) comes with a tool that guides learners with a technical
background through the HR analytics implementation process. The content is
publicly available, free of cost.

**Learn More:**[ **4 Skills HR Professionals Need to Thrive in
2020**](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/learning-development/4-skills-
hr-professionals-need-to-thrive-in-2020/)

## **Staying In Sync With an Evolving HR Analytics Landscape**

Courses like these are an excellent way to continually upskill yourself while
pursuing a full-time career in HR. It also makes your skill sets more agile,
letting you adapt to the [latest HR
trends](https://www.hrtechnologist.com/articles/employee-engagement/linkedin-
global-talent-trends-2020-latest-hr-trends/) impacting the workplace today.

At a time when the number of digital touchpoints in HR is at a constant rise,
robust analytics capabilities are crucial to collecting data from these
touchpoints and converting them into useful insights. So let's close with a
#protip: if you’re interested in upcoming HR analytics courses (or any other
ongoing course in your area of interest), check out
[ClassCentral](https://www.classcentral.com/search?q=hr), which is a MOOC
aggregator for new-age professionals.

Small moves like this can go a long way in future-proofing your competencies
in an evolving HR landscape.

# How to jumpstart a career in people analytics

Here's how you can break new ground in the field of HR analytics

![How to jumpstart a career in people analytics](https://cdn-
res.keymedia.com/cms/images/us/036/0248_637165041049621898.jpg)

BY [Rachel Ranosa](/ca/authors/rachel-ranosa) 05 Feb 2020

Share

The past five years have seen the number of HR professionals equipped with
data analytics skills rising exponentially by 242%.

Understanding analytics is no longer a nice-to-have but a core competency in
today's data-driven environment, LinkedIn's 2020 Global Talent Trends report
suggests.

**Most people need help building a data-proficient team**  
The majority of talent professionals (73%) who spoke to LinkedIn say people
analytics will be a 'major priority' for their organisation in the next five
years. However, more than half are still in need of help developing a data-
proficient team within their company.

While organisations are now beginning to make use of big data to interpret
workplace trends and issues, many have remained preoccupied with simply
collecting data.

[READ MORE: Are robots better than HR at 'reading'
emotions?](https://www.hcamag.com/ca/news/general/are-robots-better-than-hr-
at-reading-emotions/160752)

In terms of people analytics mastery, most organisations have yet to cross
over to that stage where they can confidently analyse, act on (or solve
existing problems) and - ultimately - capitalise on new opportunities using
the numbers and trends emerging from their observations.

"Providing insights to support better decision-making is the key purpose of
people analytics," noted David Green, one of the world's leading experts on
people analytics, in the report. "By bringing data to the conversation, you
can be more confident about your recommendations."

[READ MORE: Big data: Why 82% of HR departments are getting it
wrong](https://www.hcamag.com/ca/news/general/big-data-why-82-of-hr-
departments-are-getting-it-wrong/125609)

### Most Read

[![](https://cdn-
res.keymedia.com/cms/images/us/036/0248_637215071772967347.jpg)](/ca/news/general/awkward-
mistake-on-video-call-goes-viral/218861)

#### [Awkward 'mistake' on video call goes viral](/ca/news/general/awkward-
mistake-on-video-call-goes-viral/218861)

[![](https://cdn-
res.keymedia.com/cms/images/us/036/0248_637213360039891507.jpg)](/ca/news/general/covid-19-hrs-
main-challenges-revealed/218598)

#### [COVID-19: HR's main challenges revealed](/ca/news/general/covid-19-hrs-
main-challenges-revealed/218598)

[![](https://cdn-
res.keymedia.com/cms/images/us/037/0223_637214460857116193.jpg)](/ca/specialization/employee-
engagement/fun-friday-5-ted-talks-on-worklife-balance/218773)

#### [Fun Friday: 5 TED Talks on work/life
balance](/ca/specialization/employee-engagement/fun-friday-5-ted-talks-on-
worklife-balance/218773)

**Focus on a specific problem**  
For HR professionals eager to get started in people analytics, the LinkedIn
study recommends launching an analytics pilot that can zero in on a particular
problem at their organisation.

This will enable HR to work with the company's leaders in leveraging people
analytics as a problem-solving tool.

"One idea - identifying reasons for turnover - is a popular objective with
clear ROI," analysts from LinkedIn noted.

Financial services group Discovery, for example, built its own 'human capital
dashboard' that monitors attrition and collates other factors, such as the
critical skills and demographics of top performers and turnover costs. As a
result, the company now has a model that can predict attrition.

Of course, there is a diverse range of HR functions that stand to benefit from
people analytics both now and in the next five years. According to
respondents, these include:

  * Measuring employee performance (82%)
  * Strategic workforce planning (77%)
  * Identifying skills gaps (70%)
  * Evaluating recruiting channels (67%)
  * Assessing talent supply/demand (62%)
  * Identifying flight risks to improve retention (60%)
  * Reducing bias in hiring/promotions (56%)
  * Competitive intelligence (55%)
  * Predicting candidate success (47%)
  * Organisational network analysis (41%)

[READ MORE: 10 HR tech trends set to disrupt
2020](https://www.hcamag.com/ca/specialization/hr-technology/10-hr-tech-
trends-set-to-disrupt-2020/211254)

**Behavioural science background**  
But people analytics isn't only about crunching numbers.

One unique element of the practice is how it combines the disciplines of data
science and behavioural science seamlessly in its interpretation of workforce
trends.

Dr. Eric Knudsen, who leads people science research at LinkedIn, believes the
discipline of psychology lends credence to the effective practice of HR
analytics.

"We don't always behave rationally, and if we think only about the data, we'll
drive right by the motivations and behaviours that cause the patterns we're
seeing," he told HRD.

"Remember: data is decision support," he said. "Bring theory into the
conversation, and suddenly many things begin to make a lot more sense."

People, according to Knudsen, are "much more complex than the spreadsheets
their data lives in".

**' Still in its infancy'**  
"The best part is, people analytics is still in its infancy as a discipline,
so there is great opportunity for newcomers to have field-wide impact,"
Knudsen noted.

"If you're interested in getting started, your path may vary depending on
whether you're already in HR or not. If you're in HR, work with your peers to
find out what talent questions they've always grappled with, and identify what
bits of information could help you make a decision about how to fix it. You
may not have the data you need right away, but instead of throwing your hands
up (what HR has historically done), build a way to collect that information,"
he said.

"If you're asking employees for new data, communicate openly about how that
data will be used, and promise them you'll return with the insights you
learned. Follow through with that promise."

**3 practical tips to get started in people analytics**  
Knudsen's advice: "Tackle one small problem at first, and make sure your
leadership hears about it. Then tackle a slightly larger one. Then a larger
one."

"If you're in a completely different discipline to start, the same hands-on
approach applies more broadly," he said.

1) Hone your understanding and start with actual applications of data
analysis.

2) In some cases, you may have to go out and find publicly available data and
play with it - learn about it and begin training your eye to understand
methods and see patterns. You can accelerate your learning by leveraging
published and online resources.

3) Do some basic learning in both psychology and statistics.

"Where there is true interest and passion, we make time to learn," Knudsen
said. "You will find out pretty quickly if this work is right for you."

Reporting to the SVP of HR, and being a HR Partner to 'C' Suite, you will be
responsible for the HR reporting, analytics, dashboards and data across the
International region, utilising MS Excel to a high level. You will also work
on key HR projects

You will work closely with senior stakeholders across the various in-country
HR teams across the International region.

 **Client Details**

Our client in Bracknell is a major international player in their specialist
field.

 **Description**

In this role of HR Reporting and Analytics Specialist in Bracknell, working
with the HR SVP and senior stakeholders in each of the international
countries, this position will be responsible for driving simplification and
greater clarity with regard to International HR processes, identifying key
international information requirements and developing tools, such as standard
reports and easy to use information dashboards, which allow for a joined up
International view of all international people for which International leaders
have responsibility.

The position will have the responsibility for the collection and collation of
International HR metrics and the co-ordination of the International
Recruitment process and any out of cycle salary changes. The position will
also co-ordinate and finalise Lead the Way Awards and other International / HR
awards.

You will also administer and support the creation of databases for HQ
employees.

 **Profile**

For this role of HR Reporting and Analytics Specialist in Bracknell, I am
therefore looking for candidates with a proficiency in HR reporting,
analytics, dashboards, metrics and MS Excel-driven. Minimum Excel capability
would be pivot tables and vlookups.

In addition to this, the core of your earlier experience will be a strong HR
Generalist profile, with knowledge and experience across the full employee
lifecycle.

Ideally you would also be able to demonstrate excellent experience across HR
projects (an HRIS implementation would be great).

You will be working in a complex matrix international structure, with lots of
International 'C' Suite exposure, so similar exposure would certainly help.

Your stakeholder management skills will be the very best; you will be able
demonstrate creativity, possess great collaboration skills and will thrive
when working at pace.

The role is ideally to start ASAP, so you will be available on a very maximum
of one month's notice.

**Job Offer**

This HR Reporting and Analytics Specialist role offers:

  * 10% bonus scheme.
  * Pension scheme.
  * BUPA Private Health Insurance.
  * Life Assurance x 4.
  * Holidays - 25 days plus Bank Holidays rising to a maximum of 30 days plus Bank Holidays.

# CFOs Should Not Leave Workforce Analytics Solely to HR

##### People analytics remove much of the guesswork behind key management and
operational issues.

[![Linkedin Share](https://www.cfo.com/content/themes/cfo-wp-
theme/assets/img/icons/linkedin.svg)](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://www.cfo.com/people/2020/03/cfos-
should-not-leave-workforce-analytics-solely-to-hr/) [![Facebook
Share](https://www.cfo.com/content/themes/cfo-wp-
theme/assets/img/icons/facebook.svg)](http://www.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=https://www.cfo.com/people/2020/03/cfos-
should-not-leave-workforce-analytics-solely-to-hr/) [![Twitter
Share](https://www.cfo.com/content/themes/cfo-wp-
theme/assets/img/icons/twitter.svg)](https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?url=https://www.cfo.com/people/2020/03/cfos-
should-not-leave-workforce-analytics-solely-to-hr/) [![Mail
Share](https://www.cfo.com/content/themes/cfo-wp-
theme/assets/img/icons/mail.svg)](mailto:?subject=Found a great article on
CFO&body=Check this out; https://www.cfo.com/people/2020/03/cfos-should-not-
leave-workforce-analytics-solely-to-hr/)

![](https://cdn.cfo.com/content/uploads/2020/03/Jack-Freker-Buck-
CEO-e1583170492450-150x150.jpg)

##### [Jack Freker, CEO, Buck](https://www.cfo.com/author/jack-freker-ceo-
buck/ "Posts by Jack Freker, CEO, Buck")

![](https://cdn.cfo.com/content/uploads/2020/03/GettyImages-1081165980-1024x576.jpg)

With access to reams of financial data and the analytic tools to turn the
information into insight, CFOs are certainly no strangers to the power of big
data.

But finance chiefs may be less up to speed on workforce data, covering
employee performance, compensation, demographics, career history, benefits,
employee behaviors, time utilization, and attrition.

There’s no excuse for less rigor in understanding such data. For a typical
company, workforce costs total up to 70% of the cost of doing business. In
fact, several studies performed a few years ago told a convincing story:

  * EY found a [strong link](https://www.ey.com/Publication/vwLUAssets/EY-Partnering-for-performance-the-CFO-and-HR/$FILE/EY-Partnering-for-performance-the-CFO-and-HR.pdf) between CFOs’ level of involvement in strategic workforce planning and broader business performance.
  * Bersin by Deloitte found that the share prices of companies with “mature” talent analytics [exceeded](https://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/Deloitte/us/Documents/human-capital/us-cons-people-analytics-maturity.pdf) those of their competitors by 30% over a three-year period.
  * A survey by CEB (now Gartner) found that organizations could [increase gross profit margin](https://www.cebglobal.com/content/dam/cebglobal/us/EN/best-practices-decision-support/human-resources/pdfs/from-workforce-reporting-to-impactful-talent-analytics.pdf) by an average of 4%, and save roughly $12 million for every $1 billion in revenue, by taking a leadership position in workforce analytics.

#### **Strategic Insight**

Early adopters of workforce analytics aimed their effort at simply managing
the total cost of workforce (TCOW). Today, CFOs working closely with HR can
use market and industry trends to identify workforce patterns and talent
risks, forecast productivity, uncover recruitment and retention challenges,
project ROI from HR initiatives, and pinpoint leadership opportunities that
could otherwise be missed.

CFOs can use talent data to bring strategic insight to talent acquisition and
deployment by:

  * Identifying ways to lower the cost of hiring, assigning, and engaging a productive workforce
  * Ensuring compensation, benefits, and other rewards are aligned with business performance
  * Targeting better ways of capturing ROI from HR development and well-being programs
  * Determining and addressing signs of faltering performance
  * Isolating mismatches in areas like benefits utilization
  * Detecting and implementing process improvements across the workforce

Data and people analytics remove much of the guesswork behind key management
and operational issues, helping companies make smarter talent decisions, boost
performance, and even challenge conventional wisdom that can blind
organizations over time.

#### **Linking Performance and HR Programs**

Data analytics also creates new opportunities for insight into the return on
HR programs. For example, a company can look at population health and absentee
data alongside plan participation and rewards data, and then compare the
findings to productivity data in order to identify compelling corollaries
between well-being and business impact.

Finding out a particular demographic poorly utilizes health care screenings
allows a company to design responsive and more effective wellness campaigns.

People analytics can identify cost anomalies, especially in multinational
operations where jurisdictional regulations vary widely. For example, staffing
costs can vary significantly by geography due to variations in salary ranges,
benefits costs, and employment laws. Modeling allows decision-makers to
analyze these costs and determine the best geographies for specific roles.

[Predictive analytics](https://www.cfo.com/analytics/2016/10/special-report-
promise-predictive-analytics/) can reveal other management decision-making
blind spots. Suppose a company is contemplating a hiring freeze as an answer
to declining profit. That’s a common-enough scenario, but by applying
predictive analytics it may become clear that a reduced workforce and greater
workload would not meet production demands.

Further analysis may reveal that hiring contingent staff, along with paying
overtime, could cost more than the savings reaped through a hiring freeze.

#### **The Right Information**

Managing unstructured data is a growing challenge as employers try to extract
“signals” from diverse data sources, data management packages, and integration
and forecasting tools and methodologies.

The question is what specific data and analytics CFOs and CHROs should
prioritize to manage financial risk and ensure adequate return on labor costs.

How should companies break down workforce analytics to provide strategic
insight? We think there are four main areas to tap into:

_Healthcare analytics_ : The combination of population health, absentee, plan
participation, wellness, and related financial data can help better influence
the physical health of a population and help people effectively manage their
health.

_Financial analytics_ : Defined benefit plans, defined contribution plans,
equity, compensation, and other personal financial data, coupled with business
data, helps assess the ROI on reward spend and helps employees better manage
their short- and long-term financial goals.

_Diversity analytics_ : Talent management, learning and development,
succession planning, and related metrics can help to build work environments
and reward structures that meet the needs of a multi-generational workforce
and support diversity and inclusion goals. Predictive analytics can also help
to improve recruitment and retention strategies.

_Engagement analytics_ : Similar to external marketing efforts, internally
focused employee engagement analytics allow organizations to measure and
predict how people react to program design, communication outreach, and market
forces.

This combination of health, wealth, career, and engagement analytics provides
the insight needed to make the most effective investments in people and gives
them the tools they need to remain healthy and productive at work and in life.

Without that clear connection between employee performance and the
organization’s performance, managers can’t properly evaluate and reward
individuals. Employees lose sight of where they fit into the big picture and
become less engaged in the work. The company’s overall performance suffers.

#### **Analytics at the Right Time, in the Right Format**

What leaders should be looking for is a single, intuitive, and responsive
reporting system that eliminates the task of data validation and gives the CFO
the tools to start driving business performance.

One-off reports from disparate talent data sources — accomplished through
spreadsheets, manual processes, IT coding, and the like — won’t provide the
strategic insights needed to understand, predict, and monitor business risks.

Find a workforce analytics platform that:

  * Consolidates both financial and people data
  * Doesn’t solely rely on HRIS analytics for the evaluation of people data
  * Gathers full people data across performance, talent, population health, engagement, and rewards inputs
  * Establishes current-state baseline as a control measure
  * Assesses and predicts true “return on people” analysis with total cost of labor along with perceived and actual value derived from that labor, with the ability to segment to any business function
  * Benchmarks this data against peers and ideal state
  * Allows both HR and finance to model business and people scenarios for informed workforce decisions

**Looking at Performance Through the Right Lens**

Today’s CFOs are not just on point to guide company financial performance.
They need to touch everything in the company’s value chain, most definitely
including the workforce. Talent analytics must become a strategic priority.

_Jack Freker is CEO of_ _[Buck](https://buck.com/)_ _, an integrated HR and
benefits consulting, technology, and administration services provider._

people analytics mindset
